message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: 
public class TestIPRange {

    public static boolean checkIPRange(String ip, String subnet) {
        StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(ip, ".");
        int[] ipParts = new int[4];
        for (int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
            ipParts[i] = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
        }

        st = new StringTokenizer(subnet, ".");
        int[] subnetParts = new int[4];
        for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
            subnetParts[i] = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
        }

        for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
            if (ipParts[i] != subnetParts[i]) {
                return false;
            }
        }

        return true;
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String ip = "10.217.106.248";
        String subnet = "10.217.0.0";
        System.out.println(checkIPRange(ip, subnet));
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: This code uses the StringTokenizer to split the IP address and the subnet into their individual parts. It then compares each part of the IP address to the corresponding part of the subnet. If all parts match, the IP address is within the subnet range and the method returns true. Otherwise, it returns false. This code assumes that the subnet is always a /16 subnet, meaning that the first two parts of the IP address must match the subnet. If you need to check for different subnet sizes, you would need to adjust the code accordingly.
